title.narrative: CARIAA Support to International Conference on Future of African Deltas
Soutien de l'IRCAAA à la Conférence internationale sur l'avenir des deltas de l'Afrique

description.narrative:
The CARIAA team works with the selected research consortia in order to ensure that teams are enabled to broaden the scope of their research, interact with a wider range of researchers and of stakeholders working on issues related to the CARIAA program, disseminate the consortia approach and results beyond the regions of focus, in order to generate possibilities for collaboration and further work in other hot spots areas not currently covered by the program. At the same time, consistently with its launch activities, CARIAA has been identifying a set of international events where its presence has the potential to stimulate interest of stakeholders around the program and its consortia.
In this framework, the CARIAA team identified a key event in the International Conference on "Contemporary Evolution of African Floodplains and Deltas" to be held in Dar Es Salaam on May 27-30 2014.
This Conference is of high importance for the CARIAA consortium working on large deltas and migration (Project 107642 - Deltaic Environments, vulnerability and Climate Change: The role of Migration as an Adaptation and its policy implications - DECCMA), as it is the first Africa-wide event on deltas. It will gather the majority of leading researchers in the continent working on future evolution of deltaic environment, and it conveniently takes place during the period of the CARIAA launch, which is designed as a process consisting of multiple avenues selected to target the program's audiences. This event provides an additional opportunity to introduce the CARIAA program in a key international meeting, stimulating engagement with relevant stakeholder groups and research institutions. .
The DECCMA team has successfully submitted three abstracts to the conference, and a fourth is pending for approval. Presenters will elicit feedback and look for scientific collaborations in a panel dedicated to the CARIAA consortium that will be held during the conference, likely in the last session.
The three accepted abstracts are from the two African DECCMA partners, the University of Ghana and the NARSS:
1. Deltaic Environments, vulnerability and Climate Change: The role of Migration as an Adaptation and its policy implications (DECCMA), by Appeaning Addo, Codjoe, S. N. A, and Addoquaye Tagoe.
2. Characterization of coastal landforms in the Nile Delta, Egypt using remotely sensed Data Elham M. Ali, Islam Abou El-Mag, Belal M. El Liethy
3. Monitoring the hazards of land use changes over the cultivated alluvium in the apex of delta Nile west of Cairo using remote sensing data, Afify A. Afify, Hanan E. M. El Azab and Ashraf A. Mohamed
In addition to this, the panelists will situate their interventions in the broader context of the DECCMA and the CARIAA program. The panel will focus on the challenges DECCMA will face in the context of the Volta and the Nile, and it will look for collaboration with research initiatives and relevant stakeholders on migratory phenomena in other African deltas. As the audience of the conference is a balanced mix of researchers, adaptation practitioners and fewer but carefully selected policy makers, the panel discussion has the potential to raise considerable interest around the consortium.
While DECCMA participants will cover their own conference costs, this project aims to support the conference organizers in bringing to the event a number of other selected African scientists who may play a role in conducting research related to DECCMA in other African deltas, and to disseminate the conference outcomes and results, including the conference proceedings and the outcomes of the DECCMA/CARIAA panel.
